VectorsLanding.pageIntro: Two-part track: Part 1 builds the fundamentals; Part 2 builds the linear algebra core (combinations → independence → span/subspace → basis).
VectorsLanding.practiceNowHint: “Practice now” opens a pre-filtered practice session for this part.

recommended.0: Do Part 1 until orientation, shapes, norm/unit vectors, and dot product feel automatic.
recommended.1: Move to Part 2 to master independence/span/basis (these unlock everything later).
recommended.2: Revisit dot-product geometry whenever projection/decomposition feels “mystical.”

VectorsLanding.routeHint: If your material route isn’t /learn, just swap the learnHref links.

part1.title: Vectors — Part 1
part1.subtitle: Foundations, geometry intuition, NumPy shapes, and core operations

bullets.0: Vector meaning (algebra vs geometry) and ℝⁿ notation
bullets.1: Row vs column orientation + transpose (why it matters)
bullets.3: Add/subtract, scalar multiply (lists vs arrays gotcha)
bullets.6: Hadamard vs dot vs outer product (what you get)

bullets.0: Finite vs infinite vs empty vector sets
bullets.3: Span (line vs all of ℝ²) and dimension intuition
bullets.6: Coordinates in a basis (solve for c₁, c₂)

MatricesPart1Landing.pageIntro: Learn what matrices are, how to read their shapes, index/slice them like NumPy, and build intuition for multiplication, transpose, and symmetry.
MatricesPart1Landing.practiceNowHint: Tip: choose a difficulty and repeat until it feels automatic.

part1.title: Matrices: meaning, shape, and core operations
part1.subtitle: From data tables to transformations: indexing, special matrices, multiplication, transpose, symmetry

bullets.0: Read matrix shape (rows × columns) and count total entries
bullets.1: Interpret a matrix as a data table or stacked column vectors
bullets.2: Convert between math indexing and NumPy (0-based) indexing
bullets.3: Predict slice shapes using Python’s half-open intervals
bullets.4: Identify identity, diagonal, and triangular matrices
bullets.5: Understand element-wise vs matrix multiplication (* vs @), plus shifting A + λI
bullets.6: Find AB shapes, validate multiplication, and compute a single entry via dot product
bullets.7: Use transpose rules (LIVE EVIL), transpose shapes, and recognize symmetric matrices

recommended.0: Start with shape + indexing questions until you answer fast.
recommended.1: Move to multiplication shape/validity, then compute entries.
recommended.2: Finish with transpose and symmetry patterns.

MatricesPart2Landing.pageIntro: Build intuition for norms, rank, numerical tolerance, and stability. Learn why tiny noise can change answers and how to compare matrices safely in practice.
MatricesPart2Landing.practiceNowHint: Tip: start with small matrices, then increase size once the pattern feels automatic.

part2.title: Matrices: norms, rank, tolerance, and stability
part2.subtitle: Measure size, detect structure, and handle floating-point reality with ε

bullets.0: Compute the Frobenius norm from entries and interpret what it measures
bullets.1: Understand the 2-norm (spectral norm) as the maximum stretch factor
bullets.2: Compare norms and know when each is useful (fast vs geometric meaning)
bullets.3: Compute rank from pivots / RREF and connect rank to independence
bullets.4: Use an ε tolerance to define an effective rank (rankε) for noisy data
bullets.5: See how small perturbations can flip rank and why ‘nearly dependent’ matters
bullets.6: Recognize near-singular / ill-conditioned matrices and sensitivity of solutions
bullets.7: Practice robust workflows: tolerances, rounding, and safe equality checks

recommended.0: Start with Frobenius norm drills until you can compute quickly.
recommended.1: Move to rank and pivots, then compare rank vs rankε under noise.
recommended.2: Finish with stability/conditioning intuition using near-singular examples.

PythonBasicsLanding.pageIntro: Start here: printing, input, variables, strings, math, and common errors.
PythonBasicsLanding.practiceNowHint: Tip: repeat easy until it feels automatic.

recommended.1: Do 10 easy problems, then move to medium.
recommended.2: Come back and retry quizzes after a day.

PythonBasicsLanding.routeHint: Tip: You can always change subject from the top.

part1.title: Python — Part 1
part1.subtitle: print/input, variables, strings, math, comments, common errors

bullets.0: Use print() with sep/end to format output
bullets.1: Read user input and store values in variables
